descript.abstract: Layer created to identify electric plants and their capacity throughout St Vincent and The Grenadines. These plants include the two diesel power plants located at Cane Hall and Lowman’s Bay, and three hydro powered facilities located at South Rivers, Cumberland, and Richmond. The Grenadine islands are diesel powered and operated by St Vincent Electricity Services Limited (VINLEC) except on the island of Mustique which is privately operated. St. Vincent Electricity Services Limited delivers electricity to 37,619 customers in St. Vincent, Bequia, Canouan, Union Island and Mayreau where the Company operates its power plants data obtained from (VINLEC) St Vincent Electricity Services Limited.
descript.purpose: Developed to locate and understand the capacity of the electric infrastructure in St. Vincent and the Grenadines. This information will help inform the Nature Conservancy's AWE project Scientists around the world agree that climate change is indisputable. Impacts, including rising sea levels, increased storm intensity, warming temperatures and acidifying waters, dying coral reefs, shifting fish stocks, and incidence of flooding and drought, are already being felt, and are expected to continue and increase for decades to come. Nature holds some of the world’s best and most practical solutions to climate change, solutions that keep nature and people healthy, safe, and secure. The goal of At the Water’s Edge (AWE) is to demonstrate that governments and people in vulnerable coastal communities in Grenada and St. Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG) can enhance their resilience to climate change by protecting, restoring and effectively managing their marine and coastal ecosystems (also known as ecosystem-based adaptation or EBA) and strengthening local capacity for adaptation.
